Title:
Evolution and dynamics of megaplasmids with genome sizes
larger than 100 kb in the Bacillus cereus group
Keywords:
Megaplasmid, Minireplicon, TubZ/TubR, pXO1-14/pXO1-16,
Genome expansion, Bacillus cereus group
Abstract:
Background Plasmids play significant roles in the
evolution of bacterial genomes by mediating horizontal gene transfer.
Strains of the Bacillus cereus group contain up to 13 plasmids, and thus
are a good model to study plasmid dynamics and evolution. Results This
work studied the origin and evolution of Bacillus cereus group
megaplasmids (>100 kb) using the minireplicon as an index. Sixty-five
minireplicons were identified from 31 megaplasmid sequences. Based on
replication essential proteins, six minireplicon types were recognized.
Twenty-nine of the 31 megaplasmids contained two or more minireplicons.
Phylogenetic analysis of the essential protein sequences showed that
different minireplicons on each megaplasmid have different evolutionary
histories. Therefore, we speculated that megaplasmids are the results of
fusions of smaller plasmids. All plasmids of a bacterial strain must be
compatible and it was found that each individual minireplicon of
different megaplasmids in the same strain belong to different types or
subtypes. Thus, the subtypes of each minireplicon they contain determine
the incompatibilities of megaplasmids. Moreover, statistical analysis
showed that megaplasmids share more genes with chromosomes than do
smaller plasmids. This implies that megaplasmids have conferred more
advantages for chromosome dynamics than smaller plasmids during the
evolutionary history of the bacteria. We also found that 34% (443
plasmids) of the 1285 plasmids out of the B. cereus group with putative
minireplicons have two or more of them, which indicates that plasmids
fusion events are general among plasmids. Conclusions Members of the B.
cereus group are found in diverse environments, including soil, water,
and animal hosts, and they may have undergone genome expansion during
evolution. Strains of this group integrated smaller plasmids into
megaplasmids to store adaptive genes on plasmids to prevent the infinite
expansion of their chromosomes. Therefore, we speculate that
megaplasmids are the source and result of bacterial genome
expansion.
